verses.text: He soon perceived that many people of the city were strongly prejudiced against John, and ready to bring accusations against him; and taking his measures accordingly, he repaired to a place called "The Oak," in the suburbs of Chalcedon.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VIII 17:8
verses.text: This place now bears the name of Rufinus; for he was a consul, and erected here a magnificent palace, and a great church in honor of the apostles, Peter and Paul, and therefore named it the Apostolium; and appointed a congregation of monks to perform the clerical duties in the church.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VIII 17:9
verses.text: When Theophilus and the other bishops met for deliberation in this place, he judged it expedient to make no further allusion to the works of Origen, and called the monks of Scetis to repentance, promising that there would be no recollection of wrongs nor infliction of evil.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VIII 17:10
verses.text: His partisans zealously seconded his efforts, and told them that they must ask Theophilus to pardon their conduct; and as all the members of the assembly concurred in this request, the monks were troubled, and believing that it was necessary to do what they were desired by so many bishops, they used the words which it was their custom to use even when injured, and said "spare us".

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VIII 17:11
verses.text: Theophilus willingly received them into favor, and restored them to communion; and the question concerning the injuries done to the monks of Scetis was ended.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VIII 17:12
verses.text: I feel convinced that this matter would not have been so quickly settled, had Dioscorus and Ammonius been present with the other monks.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VIII 17:13
verses.text: But Dioscorus had died some time previously, and had been interred in the church dedicated to St.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VIII 17:14
verses.text: Mocius the martyr.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VIII 17:15
verses.text: Ammonius, also, had been taken ill at the very time that preparations were being made for the convocation of the council; and although he insisted upon repairing to "The Oak," yet his malady was thereby greatly increased: he died soon after his journey, and had a splendid entombment among the monks of that vicinity, and there he lies.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VIII 17:16
verses.text: Theophilus, it is said, shed tears on hearing of his death, and declared that although he had been the cause of much perplexity, there was not a monk to be found of more exalted character than Ammonius.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VIII 17:17
verses.text: It must, however, be admitted, that the death of this monk tended much to promote the success of the designs of Theophilus.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VIII 17:18
verses.text: The members of the council summoned all the clergy of Constantinople to appear before them, and threatened to depose those who did not obey the summons.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VIII 17:19
verses.text: They cited John to appear and answer; as likewise Serapion, Tigrius a presbyter, and Paul a reader.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VIII 17:20
verses.text: John acquainted them, through the medium of Demetrius, bishop of Pisinus, and of some of the other clergy, who were his friends, that he would not avoid investigation, but that he was ready, if the names of his accusers and the subject of his accusations were made known to him, to justify his proceedings before a larger council; for he did not choose to be considered insane, and to recognize his manifest enemies as judges.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VIII 17:21
verses.text: The bishops testified so much indignation at the non-compliance of John, that some of the clergy whom he had sent to the council were intimidated and did not return to him.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VIII 17:22
verses.text: Demetrius, and those who preferred his interests to all other considerations, quitted the council, and returned to him.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VIII 17:23
verses.text: The same day, a courier and a shorthand writer were dispatched from the palace to command John to repair to the bishops, and to urge the bishops to decide his cause without further delay.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VIII 17:24
verses.text: After John had been cited four times, and had appealed to a general council, no other accusation could be substantiated against him, except his refusal to obey the summons of the council; and upon this ground they deposed him.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VIII 18:1
verses.text: Chapter XVIII.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VIII 18:2
verses.text: —Sedition of the People against Theophilus; and they traduced their Rulers.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VIII 18:3
verses.text: John was recalled, and again came to the See.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VIII 18:4
verses.text: The people of Constantinople were made acquainted with the decree of the council towards the evening; and they immediately rose up in sedition.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VIII 18:5
verses.text: At the break of day they ran to the church, and shouted, among many other plans, that a larger council ought to be convened to take cognizance of the matter; and they prevented the officers, who had been sent by the emperor to convey John into banishment, from carrying the edict into execution.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VIII 18:6
verses.text: John, apprehensive lest another accusation should be preferred against him, under the pretext that he had disobeyed the mandate of the emperor, or excited an insurrection among the people, when the multitude was dispersed, secretly made his escape from the church at noon, three days after his deposition.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VIII 18:7
verses.text: When the people became aware that he had gone into exile, the sedition became serious, and many insulting speeches were uttered against the emperor and the council; and particularly against Theophilus and Severian, who were regarded as the originators of the plot.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VIII 18:8
verses.text: Severian happened to be teaching in the church at the very time that these occurrences were taking place; and he took occasion to commend the deposition of John, and stated that, even supposing him guiltless of other crimes, John deserved to be deposed on account of his pride; because, while God willingly forgives men all other sins, he resists the proud.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VIII 18:9
verses.text: At this discourse the people became restive under the wrong, and renewed their wrath, and fell into unrestrainable revolt.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VIII 18:10
verses.text: They ran to the churches, to the market-places, and even to the palace of the emperor, and with howls and groans demanded the recall of John.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VIII 18:11
verses.text: The empress was at length overcome by their importunity; and she persuaded her husband to yield to the wishes of the people.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VIII 18:12
verses.text: She quickly sent a eunuch, named Briso, in whom she placed confidence, to bring back John from Prenetus, a city of Bithynia; and protested that she had taken no part in the machinations that had been carried on against him, but had, on the contrary, always respected him as a priest and the initiator of her children.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VIII 18:13
verses.text: When John, on his journey homeward, reached the suburbs belonging to the empress, he stopped near Anaplus; and refused to re-enter the city until the injustice of his deposition had been recognized by a larger synod of bishops; but as this refusal tended to augment the popular excitement, and led to many public declamations against the emperor and the empress, he allowed himself to be persuaded to enter the city.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VIII 18:14
verses.text: The people went to meet him, singing psalms composed with reference to the circumstances; many carried light wax tapers.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VIII 18:15
verses.text: They conducted him to the church; and although he refused, and frequently affirmed that those who had condemned him ought first to reconsider their vote, yet they compelled him to take the episcopal throne, and to speak peace to the people according to the custom of the priests.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VIII 18:16
verses.text: He then delivered an extemporaneous discourse, in which, by a pleasing figure of speech, he declared that Theophilus had meditated an injury against his church, even as the king of Egypt had contemplated the violation of Sarah, the wife of the patriarch Abraham, which is recorded in the books of the Hebrews: he then proceeded to commend the zeal of the people, and to extol the emperor and the empress for their good will to him; he stirred the people to much applause and good acclaim for the emperor and his spouse, so that he had to leave his speech half ended.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VIII 19:1
verses.text: Chapter XIX.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VIII 19:2
verses.text: —Obstinancy of Theophilus.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VIII 19:3
verses.text: Enmity between the Egyptians and the Citizens of Constantinople.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VIII 19:4
verses.text: Flight of Theophilus.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VIII 19:5
verses.text: Nilammon the Ascetic.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VIII 19:6
verses.text: The Synod concerning John.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VIII 19:7
verses.text: Although Theophilus would fain have brought an accusation against John,  under the plea that he had unlawfully reinstated himself in his bishopric, yet he was deterred from doing so by the fear of offending the emperor, who had been compelled to recall John, as the means of suppressing the popular insurrection.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VIII 19:8
verses.text: Theophilus, however, received an accusation against Heraclides during the absence of the accused, in the hope of thereby authorizing the sentence of condemnation which had been issued against John.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VIII 19:9
verses.text: But the friends of Heraclides interposed, and declared that it was unjust, and contrary to ecclesiastical law, to condemn one who was absent.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VIII 19:10
verses.text: Theophilus and his partisans maintained the opposite side of the question: the people of Alexandria and of Egypt sided with them, and were opposed by the citizens of Constantinople.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VIII 19:11
verses.text: The strife between the two parties became so vehement that bloodshed ensued; many were wounded, and others slain in the contest.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VIII 19:12
verses.text: Severian, and all the bishops at Constantinople who did not support the cause of John, became apprehensive for their personal safety, and quitted the city in haste.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VIII 19:13
verses.text: Theophilus, also, fled the city at the commencement of the winter; and, in company with Isaac the monk, sailed for Alexandria.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VIII 19:14
verses.text: A wind arose which drove the vessel to Gera, a small city about fifty stadia from Pelusium.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VIII 19:15
verses.text: The bishop of this city died, and the inhabitants, I have been informed, elected Nilammon to preside over their church; he was a good man, and had attained the summit of monastic philosophy.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VIII 19:16
verses.text: He dwelt without the city, in a cell of which the door was built up with stones.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VIII 19:17
verses.text: He refused to accept the dignity of the priesthood; and Theophilus, therefore, visited him in person, to exhort him to receive ordination at his hands.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VIII 19:18
verses.text: Nilammon repeatedly refused the honor; but, as Theophilus would take no refusal, he said to him, "To-morrow, my father, you shall act as you please; to-day it is requisite that I should arrange my affairs".

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VIII 19:19
verses.text: Theophilus repaired, on the following day, to the cell of the monk, and commanded the door to be opened; but Nilammon exclaimed, "Let us first engage in prayer".

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VIII 19:20
verses.text: Theophilus complied and began to pray.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VIII 19:21
verses.text: Nilammon likewise prayed within his cell, and in the act of prayer he expired.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VIII 19:22
verses.text: Theophilus, and those who were standing with him without the cell, knew nothing at the time of what had occurred; but, when the greater part of the day had passed away, and the name of Nilammon had been loudly reiterated without his returning any answer, the stones were removed from the door, and the monk was found dead.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VIII 19:23
verses.text: They honored him with a public burial after they had clothed him in the necessary vestments, and the inhabitants built a house of prayer about his tomb; and they celebrate the day of his death, in a very marked way, until this day.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VIII 19:24
verses.text: Thus died Nilammon, if it can be called death to quit this life for another,—rather than accept a bishopric of which, with extraordinary modesty, he considered himself unworthy.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VIII 19:25
verses.text: After his return to Constantinople, John appeared to be more than ever beloved by the people.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VIII 19:26
verses.text: Sixty bishops assembled together in that city, and annulled all the decrees of the council of "The Oak".

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VIII 19:27
verses.text: They confirmed John in the possession of the bishopric, and enacted that he should officiate as a priest, confer ordination, and perform all the duties of the church usually devolving on the president.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VIII 19:28
verses.text: At this time Serapion was appointed bishop of Heraclea in Thrace.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VIII 20:1
verses.text: Chapter XX.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VIII 20:2
verses.text: —The Statue of the Empress; what happened there; the Teaching of John; Convocation of another Synod against John; his Deposition.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VIII 20:3
verses.text: Not long after these occurrences the silver statue of the empress, which is still to be seen to the south of the church opposite the grand council-chamber, was placed upon a column of porphyry on a high platform,  and the event was celebrated there with applause and popular spectacles of dances and mimes, as was then customary on the erection of the statues of the emperors.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VIII 20:4
verses.text: In a public discourse to the people John charged that these proceedings reflected dishonor on the Church.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VIII 20:5
verses.text: This remark recalled former grievances to the recollection of the empress, and irritated her so exceedingly at the insult that she determined to convene another council.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VIII 20:6
verses.text: He did not yield, but added fuel to her indignation by still more openly declaiming against her in the church; and it was at this period that he pronounced the memorable discourse commencing with the words, "Herodias is again enraged; again she dances; again she seeks to have the head of John in a basin".

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VIII 20:7
verses.text: Several bishops arrived soon after at Constantinople, and amongst them were Leontius, bishop of Ancyra, and Acacius, bishop of Berea.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VIII 20:8
verses.text: The festival of our Lord's Nativity was then at hand, and the emperor, instead of repairing to the church as usual, sent to acquaint John that he could not hold communion with him until he had cleared himself of the charges.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VIII 20:9
verses.text: John spiritedly replied that he was ready to prove his innocence; and this so intimidated his accusers that they did not dare to follow up the charges.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VIII 20:10
verses.text: The judges decided that, having been once deposed, he ought not to be admitted to a second trial.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VIII 20:11
verses.text: But they called on John to defend himself on this point only, that after he had been deposed, he had sat on the episcopal throne before a synod had reinstated him.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VIII 20:12
verses.text: In his defense he appealed to the decision of the bishops who had, subsequently to the council of "The Oak," held communion with him.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VIII 20:13
verses.text: The judges waived this argument, under the plea that those who had held communion with John were inferior in point of number to those who had deposed him, and that a canon was in force by which he stood condemned.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VIII 20:14
verses.text: Under this pretext they therefore deposed him, although the law in question had been enacted by heretics; for the Arians, after having taken advantage of various calumnies to expel Athanasius from the church of Alexandria, enacted this law from the apprehension of a change in public affairs, for they struggled to have the decisions against him remain uninvestigated.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VIII 21:1
verses.text: Chapter XXI.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VIII 21:2
verses.text: —Calamities suffered by the People after the Expulsion of John.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VIII 21:3
verses.text: The Plots against him of Assassination.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VIII 21:4
verses.text: After his deposition, John held no more assemblies in the church, but quietly remained in the episcopal dwelling-house.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VIII 21:5
verses.text: At the termination of the season of Quadragesima, on the same holy night in which the yearly festival in commemoration of the resurrection of Christ is celebrated, the followers of John were expelled from the church by the soldiers and his enemies, who attacked the people while still celebrating the mysteries.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VIII 21:6
verses.text: Since this occurrence was unforeseen, a great disturbance arose in the baptistery.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VIII 21:7
verses.text: The women wept and lamented, and the children screamed; the priests and the deacons were beaten, and were forcibly ejected from the church, in the priestly garments in which they had been officiating.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VIII 21:8
verses.text: They were charged with the commission of such disorderly acts as can be readily conceived by those who have been admitted to the mysteries, but which I consider it requisite to pass over in silence, lest my work should fall into the hands of the uninitiated.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VIII 21:9
verses.text: When the people perceived the plot, they did not use the church on the following day, but celebrated the Paschal feast in the very spacious public baths called after the Emperor Constantius.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VIII 21:10
verses.text: Bishops and presbyters, and the rest, whose right it is to administer church matters, officiated.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VIII 21:11
verses.text: Those who espoused the cause of John were present with the people.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VIII 21:12
verses.text: They were, however, driven hence, and then assembled on a spot without the walls of the city, which the Emperor Constantine, before the city had been built, had caused to be cleared and inclosed with palisades, for the purpose of celebrating there the games of the hippodrome.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VIII 21:13
verses.text: From that period, the people held separate assemblies, sometimes, whenever it was feasible, in that locality, and sometimes in another.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VIII 21:14
verses.text: They obtained the name of Johnites.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VIII 21:15
verses.text: About this time, a man who was either possessed of a devil, or who feigned to have one, was seized, having a poniard on his person, with the intention of assassinating John.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VIII 21:16
verses.text: He was apprehended by the people as one who had been hired for this plot, and led to the prefect; but John sent some bishops of his party to free him from custody before he had been questioned by torture.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VIII 21:17
verses.text: Some time afterwards, a slave of Elpidius the presbyter, who was an avowed enemy of the deacon, was seen running as swiftly as possible towards the episcopal residence.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VIII 21:18
verses.text: A passer-by endeavored to stop him, in order to ascertain the cause of so much haste; but instead of answering him, the slave plunged his poniard into him.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VIII 21:19
verses.text: Another person, who happened to be standing by, and who cried out at seeing the other wounded, was also wounded in a similar way by the slave; as was likewise a third bystander.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VIII 21:20
verses.text: All the people in the neighborhood, on seeing what had occurred, shouted that the slave ought to be arrested.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VIII 21:21
verses.text: He turned and fled.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VIII 21:22
verses.text: When those who were pursuing called out to those ahead to seize the fugitive, a man, who just then came out from the baths, strove to stop him, and was so grievously wounded that he fell down dead on the spot.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VIII 21:23
verses.text: At length, the people contrived to encircle the slave.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VIII 21:24
verses.text: They seized him, and conveyed him to the palace of the emperor, declaring that he had intended to have assassinated John, and that the crime ought to be visited with punishment.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VIII 21:25
verses.text: The prefect allayed the fury of the people by putting the delinquent into custody, and by assuring them that justice should have its course against him.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VIII 22:1
verses.text: Chapter XXII.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VIII 22:2
verses.text: —Unlawful Expulsion of John from his Bishopric.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VIII 22:3
verses.text: The Trouble which followed.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VIII 22:4
verses.text: Conflagration of the Church by Fire from Heaven.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VIII 22:5
verses.text: Exile of John to Cucusus.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VIII 22:6
verses.text: From this period the most zealous of the people guarded John alternately, stationing themselves about the episcopal residence by night and by day.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VIII 22:7
verses.text: The bishops who had condemned him complained of this conduct as a violation of the laws of the Church, declared that they could answer for the justice of the sentence that had been enacted against him, and asserted that tranquillity would never be restored among the people until he had been expelled from the city.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VIII 22:8
verses.text: A messenger having conveyed to him a mandate from the emperor enjoining his immediate departure, John obeyed, and escaped from the city, unnoticed by those who had been appointed to guard him.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VIII 22:9
verses.text: He made no other censure than that, in being sent into banishment without a legal trial or any of the forms of the law, he was treated more severely than murderers, sorcerers, and adulterers.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VIII 22:10
verses.text: He was conveyed in a little bark to Bithynia, and thence immediately continued his journey.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VIII 22:11
verses.text: Some of his enemies were apprehensive lest the people, on hearing of his departure, should pursue him, and bring him back by force, and therefore commanded the gates of the church to be closed.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VIII 22:12
verses.text: When the people who were in the public places of the city heard of what had occurred, great confusion ensued; for some ran to the seashore as if they would follow him, and others fled hither and thither, and were in great terror since the wrath of the emperor was expected to visit them for creating so much disturbance and tumult.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VIII 22:13
verses.text: Those who were within the church barred the exits still further by rushing together upon them, and by pressing upon one another.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VIII 22:14
verses.text: With difficulty they forced the doors open by the use of great violence; one party shattered them with stones, another was pulling them toward themselves, and was thus forcing the crowd backward into the building.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VIII 22:15
verses.text: Meanwhile the church was suddenly consumed on all sides with fire.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VIII 22:16
verses.text: The flames extended in all directions, and the grand house of the senatorial council, adjacent to the church on the south, was doomed.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VIII 22:17
verses.text: The two parties mutually accused each other of incendiarism.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VIII 22:18
verses.text: The enemies of John asserted that his partisans had been guilty of the deed from revenge, on account of the vote that had been passed against him by the council.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VIII 22:19
verses.text: These latter, on the other hand, maintained that they had been calumniated, and that the deed was perpetrated by their enemies, with the intention of burning them in the church.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VIII 22:20
verses.text: While the fire was spreading from late afternoon until the morning, and creeping forward to the material which was still standing, the officers who held John in custody conveyed him to Cucusus, a city of Armenia, which the emperor by letter had appointed as the place of residence for the condemned man.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VIII 22:21
verses.text: Other officers were commissioned to arrest all the bishops and clerics who had favored the cause of John, and to imprison them in Chalcedon.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VIII 22:22
verses.text: Those citizens who were suspected of attachment to John were sought out and cast into prison, and compelled to pronounce anathema against him.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VIII 23:1
verses.text: Chapter XXIII.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VIII 23:2
verses.text: —Arsacius elected to succeed John.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VIII 23:3
verses.text: The Evils wrought against the Followers of John.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VIII 23:4
verses.text: St.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VIII 23:5
verses.text: Nicarete.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VIII 23:6
verses.text: Arsacius, brother of Nectarius, who had administered the bishopric before John, was, not long afterwards, ordained as bishop of Constantinople.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VIII 23:7
verses.text: He was of a very mild disposition, and possessed of great piety; but the reputation he had acquired as a presbyter was diminished by the conduct of some of the clergy to whom he delegated his power, and who did what they pleased in his name; for their evil deeds were imputed to him.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VIII 23:8
verses.text: Nothing, however, operated so much to his disadvantage as the persecution that was carried on against the followers of John.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VIII 23:9
verses.text: They refused to hold communion, or even to join in prayer with him, because the enemies of John were associated with him; and as they persisted, as we have before stated, in holding a church in the further parts of the city, he complained to the emperor of their conduct.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VIII 23:10
verses.text: The tribune was commanded to attack them with a body of soldiers, and by means of clubs and stones he soon dispersed them.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VIII 23:11
verses.text: The most distinguished among them in point of rank, and those who were most zealous in their adherence to John, were cast into prison.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VIII 23:12
verses.text: The soldiers as is usual on such occasions, went beyond their orders, and forcibly stripped the women of their ornaments, and carried off as booty their chains, their golden girdles, necklaces, and their collars of rings; they pulled off the lobes of the ear with the earrings.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VIII 23:13
verses.text: Although the whole city was thus filled with trouble and lamentation, the affection of the people for John still remained the same, and they refrained from appearing in public.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VIII 23:14
verses.text: Many of them absented themselves from the market-place and public baths, while others, not considering themselves safe in their own houses, fled the city.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VIII 23:15
verses.text: Among the zealous men and excellent women who adopted this latter measure was Nicarete, a lady of Bithynia.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VIII 23:16
verses.text: She belonged to a noted family of the nobility, and was celebrated on account of her perpetual virginity and her virtuous life.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VIII 23:17
verses.text: She was the most modest of all the zealous women that we have ever known, and was well ordered in manner and speech and in behavior, and throughout her life she invariably preferred the service of God to all earthly considerations.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VIII 23:18
verses.text: She showed herself capable of enduring with courage and thought the sudden reversals of adverse affairs; she saw herself unjustly despoiled of the greater part of her ample patrimony without manifesting any indignation, and managed the little that remained to her with so much economy, that although she was advanced in age, she contrived to supply all the wants of her household, and to contribute largely to others.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VIII 23:19
verses.text: Since she loved a humane spirit, she also prepared a variety of remedies for the needs of the sick poor, and she frequently succeeded in curing patients who had derived no benefit from the skill of the customary physicians.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VIII 23:20
verses.text: With a devout strength which assisted her in reaching the best results, she closed her lips.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VIII 23:21
verses.text: To sum up all in a few words, we have never known a devoted woman endowed with such manners, gravity, and every other virtue.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VIII 23:22
verses.text: Although she was so extraordinary, she concealed the greater part of her nature and deeds; for by modesty of character and philosophy she was always studious of concealment.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VIII 23:23
verses.text: She would not accept of the office of deaconess, nor of instructress of the virgins consecrated to the service of the Church, because she accounted herself unworthy, although the honor was frequently pressed upon her by John.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VIII 23:24
verses.text: After the popular insurrection had been quelled, the prefect of the city appeared in public, as if to inquire into the cause of the conflagration, and the burning of the council-hall, and punished many severely; but being a pagan, he ridiculed the calamities of the Church, and delighted in its misfortunes.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VIII 24:1
verses.text: Chapter XXIV.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VIII 24:2
verses.text: —Eutropius the Reader, and the Blessed Olympian, and the Presbyter Tigrius, are persecuted on account of their Attachment to John.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VIII 24:3
verses.text: The Patriarchs.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VIII 24:4
verses.text: Eutropius, a reader,  was required to name the persons who had set fire to the church; but although he was scourged severely, although his sides and cheeks were torn with iron nails, and although lighted torches were applied to the most sensitive parts of his body, no confession could be extorted from him, notwithstanding his youth and delicacy of constitution.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VIII 24:5
verses.text: After having been subjected to these tortures, he was cast into a dungeon, where he soon afterwards expired.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VIII 24:6
verses.text: A dream of Sisinius concerning Eutropius seems worthy of insertion in this history.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VIII 24:7
verses.text: Sisinius, the bishop of the Novatians, saw in his sleep a man, conspicuous for beauty and stature, standing near the altar of the church which the Novatians erected to the honor of Stephen, the proto-martyr; the man complained of the rarity of good men, and said that he had been searching throughout the entire city, and had found but one who was good, and that one was Eutropius.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VIII 24:8
verses.text: Astonished at what he had seen, Sisinius made known the dream to the most faithful of the presbyters of his church, and commanded him to seek Eutropius wherever he might be.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VIII 24:9
verses.text: The presbyter rightly conjectured that this Eutropius could be no other than he who had been so barbarously tortured by the prefect, and went from prison to prison in quest of him.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VIII 24:10
verses.text: At length he found him, and in conversation with him made known the dream of the bishop, and besought him with tears to pray for him.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VIII 24:11
verses.text: Such are the details we possess concerning Eutropius.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VIII 24:12
verses.text: Great fortitude was evinced in the midst of these calamities by Olympias, the deaconess.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VIII 24:13
verses.text: Being dragged for this reason before the tribunal, and interrogated by the prefect as to her motives in setting fire to the church, she replied, "My past life ought to avert all suspicion from me, for I have devoted my large property to the restoration of the temples of God".

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VIII 24:14
verses.text: The prefect alleged that he was well acquainted with her past course of life.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VIII 24:15
verses.text: "Then," continued she, "you ought to appear in the place of the accuser and let another judge us".

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VIII 24:16
verses.text: As the accusation against her was wholly unsubstantiated by proofs, and as the prefect found that he had no ground on which he could justly blame her, he changed to a milder charge as if desirous of advising her, finding fault with her and the other women, because they refused communion with his bishop, although it was possible for them to repent and to change their own circumstances.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VIII 24:17
verses.text: They all through fear deferred to the advice of the prefect, but Olympias said to him, "It is not just that, after having been publicly calumniated, without having had anything proved against me in the courts, I should be obliged to clear myself of charges totally unconnected with the accusation in question.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VIII 24:18
verses.text: Let me rather take counsel concerning the original accusation that has been preferred against me.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VIII 24:19
verses.text: For even if you resort to unlawful compulsion, I will not hold communion with those from whom I ought to secede, nor consent to anything that is not lawful to the pious".

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VIII 24:20
verses.text: The prefect, finding that he could not prevail upon her to hold communion with Arsacius, dismissed her that she might consult the advocates.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VIII 24:21
verses.text: On another occasion, however, he again sent for her and condemned her to pay a heavy fine, for he imagined by this means she would be compelled to change her mind.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VIII 24:22
verses.text: But she totally disregarded the loss of her property, and quitted Constantinople for Cyzicus.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VIII 24:23
verses.text: Tigrius, a presbyter, was about the same period stripped of his clothes, scourged on the back, bound hand and foot, and stretched on the rack.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VIII 24:24
verses.text: He was a barbarian by race, and a eunuch, but not by birth.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VIII 24:25
verses.text: He was originally a slave in the house of a man in power, and on account of his faithful services had obtained his freedom.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VIII 24:26
verses.text: He was afterwards ordained as presbyter, and was distinguished by his moderation and meekness of disposition, and by his charity towards strangers and the poor.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VIII 24:27
verses.text: Such were the events which took place in Constantinople.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VIII 24:28
verses.text: Meanwhile Siricius had died, after having administered the bishopric of Rome fifteen years.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VIII 24:29
verses.text: Anastasius held the same bishopric three years, and then died, and was succeeded by Innocent.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VIII 24:30
verses.text: Flavian, who refused his consent to the deposition of John, was also dead; and Porphyry, being appointed to succeed him in the church of Antioch, where he agreed with those who had condemned John, many of those in Syria seceded from the church in Antioch, and because they made congregations among themselves, they were subjected to many cruelties.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VIII 24:31
verses.text: For the purpose of enforcing fellowship with Arsacius, and with this Porphyry and Theophilus, the bishop of Alexandria, a law was established, by the zeal of the powerful at court, that those who were orthodox should not assemble outside of the churches, and those who were not in communion with them should be expelled.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VIII 25:1
verses.text: Chapter XXV.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VIII 25:2
verses.text: —Since these Ills existed in the Church, Secular Affairs also fell into Disorder.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VIII 25:3
verses.text: The Affairs of Stilicho, the General of Honorius.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VIII 25:4
verses.text: About this period  the dissensions by which the Church was agitated were followed, as is frequently the case, by disturbances and commotions in the state.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VIII 25:5
verses.text: The Huns crossed the Ister and devastated Thrace.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VIII 25:6
verses.text: The robbers in Isauria gathered in great numbers and ravaged cities and villages as far as Caria and Phoenicia.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VIII 25:7
verses.text: Stilicho, the general of Honorius, a man who had attained great power, if any one ever did, and had under his sway the flower of the Roman and of the barbarian soldiery, conceived feelings of enmity against the rulers who held office under Arcadius, and determined to set the two empires at enmity with each other.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VIII 25:8
verses.text: He caused Alaric, the leader of the Goths, to be appointed by Honorius to the office of general of the Roman troops, and sent him into Illyria; whither also he dispatched Jovius, the praetorian prefect, and promised to join them there with the Roman soldiers in order to add that province to the dominions of Honorius.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VIII 25:9
verses.text: Alaric marched at the head of his troops from the barbarous regions bordering on Dalmatia and Pannonia, and came to Epirus; and after waiting for some time there, he returned to Italy.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VIII 25:10
verses.text: Stilicho was prevented from fulfilling his agreement to join Alaric, by some letters which were transmitted to him from Honorius.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VIII 25:11
verses.text: These events happened in the manner narrated.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VIII 26:1
verses.text: Chapter XXVI.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VIII 26:2
verses.text: —Two Epistles from Innocent, the Pope of Rome, of which one was addressed to John Chrysostom, and the other to the Clergy of Constantinople concerning John.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VIII 26:3
verses.text: Innocent,  bishop of Rome,  was extremely indignant when apprised of the measures that had been adopted against John, and condemned the whole proceedings.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VIII 26:4
verses.text: He then turned his attention to the convocation of an oecumenical council, and wrote to John and to the clergy of Constantinople in part.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VIII 26:5
verses.text: Subjoined are the two letters, precisely as I found them, translated from the Latin into Greek.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VIII 26:6
verses.text: "Innocent, to the beloved brother John.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VIII 26:7
verses.text: "Although one conscious of his own innocence ought to expect every blessing and to ask for mercy from God, yet it seems well to us to send you a befitting letter by Cyriacus, the deacon, and to counsel you to long-suffering, lest the contumely cast upon you should have more power in subduing your courage than the testimony of a good conscience in encouraging you to hope.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VIII 26:8
verses.text: It is not requisite to teach you, who are the teacher and pastor of so great a people, that God always tries the best of men to see whether they will continue in the height of patience, and will not give way to any labor of suffering; and how true it is that the conscience is a firm thing against all that befalls us unjustly, and unless one be moved in these misfortunes by patience, he furnishes a ground for evil surmising.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VIII 26:9
verses.text: For he ought to endure everything, who first trusts in God, and then in his own conscience.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VIII 26:10
verses.text: Especially when an excellent and good man can exercise himself in endurance, he cannot be overcome; for the Holy Scriptures guard his thoughts, and the devout lections, which we expound to the people, abound in examples.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VIII 26:11
verses.text: These Scriptures assure us that almost all the saints are variously and continuously afflicted, and are tested by some investigation, and so have come to the crown of patience.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VIII 26:12
verses.text: Let thy conscience encourage thy love, O most honored brother; for that faculty amid tribulations possesses an encouragement for virtue.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VIII 26:13
verses.text: For since Christ, the Master, is observing, the purified conscience will station you in the haven of peace".

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VIII 26:14
verses.text: "Innocent, the bishop, to the presbyters, deacons, and all the clergy, and to the people of the church of Constantinople under John, the bishop, greeting to you, beloved brethren.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VIII 26:15
verses.text: "From the letters of your love that you forwarded to me through Germanus, the presbyter, and Cassianus, the deacon, I have learned, with anxious solicitude, the scenes of evil which you have placed before our eyes.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VIII 26:16
verses.text: I have frequently seen during its repeated reading with what calamities and labors the faith is wearied.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VIII 26:17
verses.text: Only the consolation of patience heals such a state of affairs.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VIII 26:18
verses.text: Our God will shortly put an end to such tribulations, and they will eventually tend to your profit.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VIII 26:19
verses.text: But we recognized with approbation your proposition, placed at the beginning of the letter of your love; to wit, that this very consolation is necessary, and embraces many proofs of your patience; for our consolation, which we ought to have conveyed, you have anticipated in your epistle.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VIII 26:20
verses.text: Our Lord is wont to furnish this patience to the suffering, in order that when they fall into tribulations, the servants of Christ may encourage themselves; for they should reason within themselves that what they suffer has happened previously to the saints.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VIII 26:21
verses.text: And even we ourselves derive comfort from your letters, for we are not strangers to your sufferings; but we are disciplined in you.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VIII 26:22
verses.text: Who, indeed, can endure to witness the errors introduced by those who were bound especially to be enthusiasts for the quiet of peace and for its concord? But far from maintaining peace, they expel guiltless priests from the front seat of their own churches.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VIII 26:23
verses.text: John, our brother and fellow-minister and your bishop, has been the first to suffer this unjust treatment without being allowed a hearing.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VIII 26:24
verses.text: No accusation was brought, none was heard.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VIII 26:25
verses.text: What proposition was it that was nullified, so that no show of judgment might arise or be sought? Others were seated in the places of living priests, as though any who began from such discord would be able to possess anything or do anything rightly in any one's judgment.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VIII 26:26
verses.text: We have never known such audacities to have been done by our fathers.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VIII 26:27
verses.text: They rather prohibited such innovations by refusing to give power to any one to be ordained in another's place while the occupant was living, since he is unable to be a bishop who is unjustly substituted.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VIII 26:28
verses.text: "With respect to the observance of canons, we declare that those defined at Nicaea are alone  entitled to the obedience and recognition of the Catholic Church.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VIII 26:29
verses.text: If any individuals should attempt to introduce other canons, at variance with those of Nicaea, and such as are a compilation by heretics, such canons ought to be rejected by the Catholic Church, for it is not lawful to add the inventions of heretics to the Catholic canons.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VIII 26:30
verses.text: For they always wish to belittle the decision of the Nicene fathers through opponents and lawless men.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VIII 26:31
verses.text: We say, then, that the canons we have censured are not only to be disregarded, but to be condemned with the dogmas of heretics and schismatics, even as they have been formerly condemned at the council of Sardica by the bishops who were our predecessors.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VIII 26:32
verses.text: For it would be better, O most honored brethren, that these transactions be condemned, than that any actions should be confirmed contrary to the canons.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VIII 26:33
verses.text: "What measures ought we to adopt now in the present circumstances against such deeds? It is necessary that there be a synodical investigation, and a synod we long ago said should be gathered.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VIII 26:34
verses.text: There are no other means of arresting the fury of the tempest.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VIII 26:35
verses.text: In order that we may attain this it will be profitable meanwhile for that healing to be exalted which comes by the will of the great God and of His Christ, our Lord.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VIII 26:36
verses.text: We shall thus behold the cessation of all the woes which have been excited by the envy of the devil, and which have served as trials for our faith.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VIII 26:37
verses.text: If we remain steadfast in the faith, there is nothing that we ought not to expect from the Lord.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VIII 26:38
verses.text: We are constantly watching for the opportunity of convening an oecumenical council, whereby, in accordance with the will of God, an end may be put to these harassing commotions.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VIII 26:39
verses.text: Let us, then, endure in the interval, and, fortified by the wall of patience, let us trust in the help of our God for the restoration of all things.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VIII 26:40
verses.text: "We had previously been made acquainted with all that you have related concerning your trials, by our fellow-bishops Demetrius, Cyriacus, Eulysius, and Palladius, who visited Rome at different periods and are now with us; from them we had learned all the details by a complete inquiry".

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VIII 27:1
verses.text: Chapter XXVII.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VIII 27:2
verses.text: —The Terrible Events which resulted from the Treatment of John.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VIII 27:3
verses.text: Death of the Empress Eudoxia.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VIII 27:4
verses.text: Death of Arsacius.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VIII 27:5
verses.text: And further concerning Atticus, the Patriarch, his Birthplace, and Character.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VIII 27:6
verses.text: Such were the letters of Innocent from which the opinion which he entertained of John may readily be inferred.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VIII 27:7
verses.text: About the same period some hailstones of extraordinary magnitude fell at Constantinople and in the suburbs of the city.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VIII 27:8
verses.text: Four days afterwards, the wife of the emperor died.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VIII 27:9
verses.text: These occurrences were by many regarded as indications of Divine wrath on account of the persecution that had been carried on against John.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VIII 27:10
verses.text: For Cyrinus, bishop of Chalcedon, one of his principal calumniators, had long previously terminated his life in the midst of great bodily agony, arising from the accident that had occurred to his foot, and the consequent necessary amputation of the leg by the physicians.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VIII 27:11
verses.text: Arsacius, too, died after he had presided but a very short period over the church of Constantinople.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VIII 27:12
verses.text: Many candidates were proposed as his successor; and four months after his decease, Atticus, a presbyter, of the clergy of Constantinople, and one of the enemies of John, was ordained.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VIII 27:13
verses.text: He was a native of Sebaste in Armenia.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VIII 27:14
verses.text: He had been instructed from his youth in the principles of monastic philosophy by monks of the Macedonian heresy.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VIII 27:15
verses.text: These monks, who then enjoyed a very high reputation at Sebaste for philosophy, were of the discipline of Eustathius, to whom allusion has been already made as bishop there, and a leader of the best monks.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VIII 27:16
verses.text: When Atticus attained the age of manhood, he embraced the tenets of the Catholic Church.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VIII 27:17
verses.text: He possessed more by nature than by learning, and became a participant in affairs, and was as skillful in carrying on intrigues as in evading the machinations of others.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VIII 27:18
verses.text: He was of a very engaging disposition, and was beloved by many.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VIII 27:19
verses.text: The discourses which he delivered in the church did not rise above mediocrity; and although not totally devoid of erudition, they were not accounted by his auditors of sufficient value to be preserved in writing.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VIII 27:20
verses.text: Being intent, if an opportunity offered itself anywhere, he exercised himself in the most approved Greek authors; but lest, in conversation about these writers, he might appear unlettered, he frequently concealed what he did know.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VIII 27:21
verses.text: It is said that he manifested much zeal in behalf of those who entertained the same sentiments as himself, and that he rendered himself formidable to the heterodox.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VIII 27:22
verses.text: When he wished he could easily throw them into alarm; but he at once transformed himself and would appear meek.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VIII 27:23
verses.text: Such is the information which those who knew the man have furnished.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VIII 27:24
verses.text: John acquired great celebrity even in his exile.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VIII 27:25
verses.text: He possessed ample pecuniary resources, and being besides liberally supplied with money by Olympias, the deaconess, and others, he purchased the liberty of many captives from the Isaurian robbers, and restored them to their families.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VIII 27:26
verses.text: He also administered to the necessities of many who were in want; and by his kind words comforted those who did not stand in need of money.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VIII 27:27
verses.text: Hence he was exceedingly beloved not only in Armenia, where he dwelt, but by all the people of the neighboring countries, and the inhabitants of Antioch and of the other parts of Syria, and of Cilicia, who frequently sought his society.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VIII 28:1
verses.text: Chapter XXVIII.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VIII 28:2
verses.text: —Effort of Innocent, Bishop of Rome, to recall John through a Council.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VIII 28:3
verses.text: Concerning those who were sent by him to make Trial of the Matter.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VIII 28:4
verses.text: The Death of John Chrysostom.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VIII 28:5
verses.text: Innocent, bishop of Rome, was very anxious, as appears by his former letter, to procure the recall of John.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VIII 28:6
verses.text: He sent five bishops and two presbyters of the Roman church, with the bishops who had been delegated as ambassadors to him from the East, to the emperors Honorius and Arcadius, to request the convocation of a council, and solicit them to name time and place.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VIII 28:7
verses.text: The enemies of John at Constantinople framed a charge as though these things were done to insult the Eastern emperor, and caused the ambassadors to be ignominiously dismissed as if they had invaded a foreign government.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VIII 28:8
verses.text: John was at the same time condemned by an imperial edict to a remoter place of banishment, and soldiers were sent to conduct him to Pityus; the soldiers were soon on hand, and effected the removal.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VIII 28:9
verses.text: It is said that during this journey, Basiliscus, the martyr, appeared to him at Comani, in Armenia, and apprised him of the day of his death.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book VIII 28:10
verses.text: Being attacked with pain in the head, and being unable to bear the heat of the sun, he could not prosecute his journey, but closed his life in that town.
